case_name: Shiam Lal Radhey Lal v. Agra Mahapalika

facts.text: Appellants are partners of the firm Shiam Lal Radhey Lal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the partners of the firm Shiam Lal Radhey Lal.

facts.text: First respondent is the Agra Mahapalika and second respondent is the Health Officer of the Mahapalika.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent is the Agra Mahapalika the second respondent is the Health Officer of the Mahapalika.

facts.text: Military Dairy Farm at Agra possessed a quantity of wheat flour declared unfit for human consumption.

anchor.surface_text: The Military Dairy Farm at Agra was in possession of a certain quantity of wheat flour. It was declared unfit for human companysumption.

facts.text: Appellants purchased the unfit wheat flour for use as lehi, manure and ratab for consumption by animals.

anchor.surface_text: It was purchased for the firm. According to the appellants, it was fit for being used as lehi, manure and ratab for companysumption by animals.

facts.text: Appellants started selling the flour from March 20, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants started selling the flour from March 20, 1945.

facts.text: On May 17, 1945, second respondent reported to Administrator of Nagarpalika that flour was decomposed and unfit for human consumption.

anchor.surface_text: On May 17, 1945, the second respondent reported to the Administrator of the Nagarpalika that the flour was in a decomposed and deteriorated companydition

facts.text: Appellants set up a placard stating the flour is condemned atta and unfit for consumption.

anchor.surface_text: He admitted in the report that the firm of the appellants has set up a placard to say it  flour  is companydemned atta and unfit for companysumption.

facts.text: Nagarpalika reported the matter to District Magistrate, Agra.

anchor.surface_text: The Nagarpalika reported the matter to the District Magistrate, Agra.

facts.text: On July 26, 1945, order issued under s.144 Cr.P.C. prohibiting appellants from selling flour for one month.

anchor.surface_text: On July 26, 1945 an order was issued under s. 144 Cr. P. C. prohibiting the appellants from selling the flour for one month.

facts.text: Order under s.144 extended till September 20, 1945 by order dated September 18, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: This order was extended till September 20, 1945 by another order, dated September 18, 1945.

facts.text: Appellants prosecuted for offences under ss.4 and 14 of U.P. Prevention of Adulteration Act and s.273 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were prosecuted for offences under ss. 4 and 14 of the U.P. Prevention of Adulteration Act and s. 273 I.P.C.

facts.text: Flour seized by magistrate's order and kept in custody of appellants until further orders.

anchor.surface_text: The flour was seized by the order of the magistrate And kept in the custody of the appellants until further orders.

facts.text: Magistrate acquitted appellants on September 5, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate acquitted the appellants on September 5, 1945.

facts.text: Magistrate directed Health Officer to take possession of atta and regulate its disposal.

anchor.surface_text: Since this Atta is numberious ,to public health and it is number possible to prevent its reaching companysumers  even though the accused had best intention  without effective regulation

facts.text: On September 17, 1945, second respondent issued order under s.244 U.P. Municipalities Act permitting disposal with conditions.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1945 the second respondent issued an order under s. 244 of the U.P. Municipalities Act.

facts.text: Order dated September 17, 1945 required approved salesman, separate books, sale only for lehi to book-binders etc., weekly returns.

anchor.surface_text: The order was with respect to 2048 bags of Atta seized by the magistrate in companynection with the criminal case The order permitted the appellants to dispose of the flour subject to the following companyditions

facts.text: Appellants by letter dated September 22, 1945 requested permission to sell for animal food after mixing gram dal chuni.

anchor.surface_text: By their letter, dated September 22, 1945, the appellants replied to this letter. They said that the Atta companyld also be used for animal food

facts.text: Respondents by letter dated September 27, 1945 approved Nanu Mal as salesman and emphasized compliance, no reply on animal food.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, by their letter, dated September 27, 1945, informed them that the appointment of Nanu Mal as salesman was approved.

facts.text: On October 6, 1945, second respondent permitted sale for animal food under certain conditions.

anchor.surface_text: By his letter, dated October 6, 1945, the second respondent, however, permitted them to sell the flour for animal food under certain companyditions.

facts.text: On October 8, 1945, second respondent issued directions under s.244 including no sale for dairy animals, min one bag, labels, inspection.

anchor.surface_text: By the letter, dated October 8, 1945, the second respondent issued the following directions to the appellants under S. 244 of the Municipalities Act

facts.text: Trial court decreed the suit for appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt decreed the suit, but the High Court of Allahabad reversed the decree and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed trial court decree and dismissed suit on May 25, 1962 in Appeal No. 328 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and decree dated May 25, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Appeal No. 328 of 1950.

facts.text: Court holds respondents not liable for stoppage from July 26 to September 20, 1945 due to magistrate's s.144 order.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the respondents are liable for the stoppage of sale from July 26 to September 20, 1945.

facts.text: Appellants claim orders under s.244 between Sept 17 and Oct 8 invalid and malafide.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants ground their claim on the respondents orders passed under section 244 of the Municipalities Act between September 17 and October 8, 1945.

facts.text: Court finds orders under s.244 invalid as flour sale not appearing intended for human consumption.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companyld number therefore take action under S. 244. The orders, passed by them under section 244 are invalid.

facts.text: Appellants placed sign-board stating flour unfit for human consumption.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the evidence on record that the appellants had taken steps to inform the buyers that the flour was unfit for human companysumption.

facts.text: Respondents admit appellants placed placard that flour unfit for human consumption.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by the respondents that the appellants had placed a placard informing that the flour was unfit for human companysumption.
The suit was grounded on tortious liability. The trial court decreed the suit, but the High Court of Allahabad reversed the decree and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1945 the second respondent issued an order under s. 244 of the U.P. Municipalities Act. The order was with respect to 2048 bags of Atta seized by the magistrate in connection with the criminal case The order permitted the appellants to dispose of the flour subject to the following conditions  1  they should engage a salesman approved by the second respondent to sell the Atta  2  they should keep a separate stock book and sales-book in respect of the Atta. In the sales book the names and addresses of all buyers should be mentioned. There should be a column for the signature of the buyers  3  the Atta should be sold only for being used as lehi to recognised book-binders and shoe-merchants etc. and  4  they should submit weekly return of sale to the Nagarpalika.

concepts.interpretation: Applies only if article of food appears objectively intended for direct human consumption and is unfit; requires facts warranting reasonable belief of human consumption intent, not officer's subjective satisfaction; does not cover sales for animal feed even if indirect human use.

anchor.surface_text: Section 239 materially provides that whenever it appears to the District Magistrate to be necessary for the preservation of the public peace or order, he may prohibit or regulate, the slaughter within the limits of a municipality of animal or animals of any specified description for purposes other than sale and prescribe the mode and route in and by which such animals shall be brought to, and meat shall be conveyed from, the place of slaughter.

concepts.interpretation: Uses subjective 'appears to him' standard, unlike objective standard in s.244(1).

anchor.surface_text: Section 242 reads .Whoever feeds or allows to be fed, an animal which is kept for dairy purposes, or may be used for food, on filthy or deleterious substance, shall be liable to conviction to a fine which may extend to fifty rupees.

concepts.interpretation: Separate provision penalizing feeding deleterious substances to dairy or food animals, indicating s.244(1) not intended to cover animal feed sales.

anchor.surface_text: Section 243 is in these words The President, the executive officer, or the medical officer of health and, if authorised in this behalf by resolution, any other member, officer or servant of the board may, without notice, at any period of the day or night, enter into and inspect a market, shop, stall or place used for the sale of food or drink for man, or as a slaughterhouse, or for the sale of drugs and inspect and examine any articles of food or drink, or any animal or drug which may be therein.

anchor.surface_text: The phrase an article of food or drink appears to be intended for the consumption of man does not contemplate any subjective satisfaction. The seller should intend to sell an article of food for human consumption. His intention is an objective fact. There should be present some facts or circumstances which would incline a reasonable man to believe that the sale-of an article of food or drink or an animal was intended for human consumption.

concepts.interpretation: Intention determined objectively by facts/circumstances that would lead reasonable person to believe sale for human consumption.

issues.text: whether the respondents are liable to pay damages in the circumstances of the case

anchor.surface_text: The two central issues are  1  whether the respondents are liable to pay damages in the circumstances of the case and  2  if so, what is the quantum of their liability.

issues.text: if so, what is the quantum of their liability

anchor.surface_text: and  2  if so, what is the quantum of their liability. On the first issue the High Court has held that the respondents are number liable at all.

issues.text: whether they are liable for loss incurred by the appellants for any period after September 20, 1945

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the respondents are liable for the stoppage of sale from July 26 to September 20, 1945. During that period the sale was stopped by an order of the magistrate under s. 144 Cr. P.C. The question is whether they are liable for loss incurred by the appellants for any period after September 20, 1945.

issues.text: whether the respondents orders passed under section 244 of the Municipalities Act between September 17 and October 8, 1945 are invalid and malafide

anchor.surface_text: The appellants ground their claim on the respondents orders passed under section 244 of the Municipalities Act between September 17 and October 8, 1945. They say that the orders are invalid and malafide.

issues.text: whether the magistrate had power to make that order

anchor.surface_text: The magistrates order can afford them numberprotection. The magistrate had numberpower to make that order. Counsel for the respondents did number bring to our numberice any provision of law empowering the magistrate to make that order.

issues.text: as to whether its sale appeared to be intended for human companysumption

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the flour was unfit for human companysumption. So the real issue is as to whether its sale appeared to be intended for human companysumption.

issues.text: whether the phrase 'an article of food or drink or an animal appears to be intended for the companysumption of man' contemplates subjective satisfaction of the inspecting officer

His subjective, satisfaction about this matter is decisive. ... The phrase an article of ,food or drink appears to be intended for the companysumption of man does number companytemplate any subjective satisfaction.

issues.text: whether s. 244(1) aims to prevent a direct as well as an indirect sale for human companysumption

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also taken the view that sub-section  1  aims to prevent a direct as well as an indirect sale for human companysumption. According to the High Court, if the flour is sold for feeding milch animals or animals whose flesh is eaten, it would be a sale for human companysumption. In our opinion, S. 244 1  is number susceptible of those meanings.

Loss was cause to them on account of delay in sale due to their intervention.

arguments.claim: Respondents not liable for stoppage Jul 26 to Sep 20 1945

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the respondents are liable for the stoppage of sale from July 26 to September 20, 1945.

arguments.claim: Magistrate had no power to direct possession and regulation of atta on Sep 5

anchor.surface_text: The magistrates order can afford them no protection. The magistrate had no power to make that order.

arguments.claim: s.244(1) requires objective appearance that article intended for human consumption, not subjective satisfaction of officer

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court, the phrase appears to be intended for the consumption of man contemplates that the sale of an article of food should appear to the inspecting officer to be intended for human consumption. His subjective, satisfaction about this matter is decisive. ... The phrase an article of food or drink appears to be intended for the consumption of man does not contemplate any subjective satisfaction.

arguments.claim: s.244(1) does not cover indirect sale for human consumption via animal feed

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also taken the view that sub-section 1 aims to prevent a direct as well as an indirect sale for human consumption. According to the High Court, if the flour is sold for feeding milch animals or animals whose flesh is eaten, it would be a sale for human consumption. In our opinion, S. 244 1 is not susceptible of those meanings.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished from s.239; s.242 covers animal feed separately

arguments.claim: Evidence shows appellants informed buyers flour unfit for human consumption via placard and sign-board

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the evidence on record that the appellants had taken steps to inform the buyers that the flour was unfit for human consumption.

arguments.claim: Respondents admit placard placed stating unfit for human consumption

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by the respondents that the appellants had placed a placard informing that the flour was unfit for human consumption.

arguments.claim: Oral evidence does not show selling for human consumption; mixing maize not indicative

anchor.surface_text: Their oral evidence does not show that the appellants were selling flour for human consumption. The appellants mixed maize flour with the condemned flour. But this act also would not show that they intended to sell the mixed flour for human food.

arguments.claim: s.244 phrase read in context of s.243 implies sale appearing for human consumption

anchor.surface_text: Section 244 1 is not happily worded. However, when the phrase an article of food or drink or an animal appears to be intended for the consumption of man is read in the context of s. 243, the implication of the phrase becomes plain.

arguments.claim: s.244 language different from s.239; no 'appears to him'

anchor.surface_text: The language of sub-section 1 of s. 244 is radically different from the language of s. 239. Under s. 239 the District Magistrate is empowered to act whenever it appears to him to be necessary for the preservation of public peace or order. These words are not used in s. 244 1 .

arguments.claim: s.242 separately penalizes feeding deleterious substances to dairy/food animals

anchor.surface_text: If an article mentioned in sub-section 1 of s. 244 is sold for feeding an animal which is kept for dairy purposes, the seller shall be liable on conviction to a fine which may extend to fifty rupees. See section 242 .

arguments.claim: s.244 orders invalid as no facts warranting belief of intent for human consumption

anchor.surface_text: The respondents could not therefore take action under S. 244. The orders, passed by them under section 244 are invalid.

arguments.claim: Bona fide motive does not protect from liability for illegal orders

anchor.surface_text: It is immaterial that the respondents had acted bona fide and in the interest of preservation of public health. Their motive may be good but their orders are illegal. They would accordingly be liable for any loss caused to the appellants by their action.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also taken the view that sub-section 1 aims to prevent a direct as well as an indirect sale for human consumption. According to the High Court, if the flour is sold for feeding milch animals or animals whose flesh is eaten, it would be a sale for human consumption.

holdings.text: The respondents are not liable for the stoppage of sale from July 26 to September 20, 1945 as the sale was stopped by an order of the magistrate under s.144 Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the respondents are liable for the stoppage of sale from July 26 to September 20, 1945. During that period the sale was stopped by an order of the magistrate under s. 144 Cr. P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale prohibited by valid magistrate order under CrPC s.144, independent of respondents' actions.

holdings.text: The magistrate had no power to direct the Health Officer to take possession of the atta and regulate its disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The magistrates order can afford them numberprotection. The magistrate had numberpower to make that order. Counsel for the respondents did number bring to our numberice any provision of law empowering the magistrate to make that order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory provision empowers magistrate to issue such directive post-acquittal.

holdings.text: Section 244(1) of U.P. Municipalities Act requires objective facts or circumstances warranting a reasonable belief that the article appears intended for human consumption, not the inspecting officer's subjective satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: The phrase an article of ,food or drink appears to be intended for the companysumption of man does number companytemplate any subjective satisfaction. The seller should intend to sell an article of food for human companysumption. His intention is an objective fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual difference from s.239 ('appears to him'); read in context of s.243 (inspection of human food sale places); intention as objective fact.

holdings.text: Section 244(1) does not apply to prevent indirect sales for human consumption through animal feed for dairy or meat animals.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also taken the view that sub-section  1  aims to prevent a direct as well as an indirect sale for human companysumption. According to the High Court, if the flour is sold for feeding milch animals or animals whose flesh is eaten, it would be a sale for human companysumption. In our opinion, S. 244 1  is number susceptible of those meanings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language contemplates direct human consumption; s.242 separately penalizes feeding deleterious substances to such animals; distinguishes s.239.

holdings.text: The facts here (placard/sign-board stating unfit for human consumption, no contrary oral evidence) do not show objective appearance of intent for human consumption.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the evidence on record that the appellants had taken steps to inform the buyers that the flour was unfit for human companysumption. They had placed a sign-board in which it was clearly stated that the flour was- unfit for human companysumption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence including respondents' admission of placard and lack of proof of human sales; mixing not indicative.

holdings.text: Orders under s.244 of U.P. Municipalities Act passed between September 17 and October 8, 1945 are invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companyld number therefore take action under S. 244. The orders, passed by them under section 244 are invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No objective appearance of human consumption intent justifying action under s.244(1).

holdings.text: Respondents are liable in tort for damages caused by their illegal orders under s.244 despite acting bona fide in public interest.

anchor.surface_text: It is immaterial that the respondents had acted bona fide and in the interest of preservation of public health. There motive may be good but their orders are illegal. They would accordingly be liable for any loss caused to the appellants by their action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illegal administrative action causing loss attracts tortious liability regardless of motive.

holdings.text: Case remanded to High Court for determination of quantum of damages.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has number recorded any finding on the quantum of their liability. In view of our finding that the respondents are liable, the case will number have to go back to the High Court for giving a finding on the issue regarding damages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No finding by High Court; necessary for decree.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
